snippet.textDisplay:
The way I see it at the minute, electric cars are worse in more or less every way that matters but are stupidly expensive for what you get.
The range isn't such a issue, its that combined with the charge times, and the lack of charging facilities. For example I would have nowhere to charge one up.
A petrol car is just so much cheaper, isn't any different in regards to the environmental effect, and is infinitely more practical. So for me, I'll be keeping with internal combustion for as long as possible
snippet.textOriginal:
The way I see it at the minute, electric cars are worse in more or less every way that matters but are stupidly expensive for what you get.
The range isn't such a issue, its that combined with the charge times, and the lack of charging facilities. For example I would have nowhere to charge one up.
A petrol car is just so much cheaper, isn't any different in regards to the environmental effect, and is infinitely more practical. So for me, I'll be keeping with internal combustion for as long as possible

snippet.textDisplay: Charging phone from 0-100% or using any bluetooth connection consumes the same amount of energy as you would when accidentally pushing the gas for a moment. A phone battery holds 0.02% of the energy of those car batteries. You could charge 4200 phones from flat to full.
snippet.textOriginal: Charging phone from 0-100% or using any bluetooth connection consumes the same amount of energy as you would when accidentally pushing the gas for a moment. A phone battery holds 0.02% of the energy of those car batteries. You could charge 4200 phones from flat to full.

snippet.textDisplay: It's great that one can drive across England on a single charge.  If I were trying to drive from San Francisco to Los Angeles, the best of these cars would get less than 3/4 the way to Los Angeles.  There isn't much out there on Interstate 5 between SF and LA.  It can be 75 miles between charging stations on this route.  When you do charge in the dusty valley, enjoy the cow smell for the next hour in 100 plus degree heat (38-40 Celsius).
snippet.textOriginal: It's great that one can drive across England on a single charge.  If I were trying to drive from San Francisco to Los Angeles, the best of these cars would get less than 3/4 the way to Los Angeles.  There isn't much out there on Interstate 5 between SF and LA.  It can be 75 miles between charging stations on this route.  When you do charge in the dusty valley, enjoy the cow smell for the next hour in 100 plus degree heat (38-40 Celsius).

snippet.textDisplay: Good video.  E-cars, with their present range, will work for people in a number of situations.  But I live in the western US, and here we drive a lot of miles to go places.  So charging a car becomes a hassle.  I can fill up my tank in 15 minutes total time and go for another 500 miles.  And I don't have to look for a charging station.  I would get an E-car only for local driving around town, and use it for shopping trips and such.
snippet.textOriginal: Good video.  E-cars, with their present range, will work for people in a number of situations.  But I live in the western US, and here we drive a lot of miles to go places.  So charging a car becomes a hassle.  I can fill up my tank in 15 minutes total time and go for another 500 miles.  And I don't have to look for a charging station.  I would get an E-car only for local driving around town, and use it for shopping trips and such.

snippet.textDisplay: Maybe I'll buy one in about....10 or 15 years if the battery technology improves in a way that they may become equal or better than diesel/gas vehicles. Not to mention the acquisition price and later the price you will have to pay for a new battery. My old Hyundai Santa Fé 4wd will give me about 420 miles of autonomy and refuels in about.....120 seconds. These e-cars take 4 to 10 hours to recharge if you can find one where you need it. These cars are great to use in a city where you can always recharge them over night at home. For now, a good hybrid would be fine.
snippet.textOriginal: Maybe I'll buy one in about....10 or 15 years if the battery technology improves in a way that they may become equal or better than diesel/gas vehicles. Not to mention the acquisition price and later the price you will have to pay for a new battery. My old Hyundai Santa Fé 4wd will give me about 420 miles of autonomy and refuels in about.....120 seconds. These e-cars take 4 to 10 hours to recharge if you can find one where you need it. These cars are great to use in a city where you can always recharge them over night at home. For now, a good hybrid would be fine.

snippet.textDisplay: I love that we are all tuning in to see a bunch of grossly inefficient vehicles for there efficiency 😂🤣😜. Efficient takes into account total cost to travel said amount of kilometres during the life of the vehicle including maintenance, time spent charging or filling up the vehicle. Also I would include trips to dealerships or repair shops. Ease of life style also matters. As it stands electric vehicles are about as efficient as cars from the 50’s. But I do have hope that one day we will be able to justify purchasing electric vehicles. Remember if everyone drove an ev the cost of electricity would exceed the price of gasoline. We need nuclear power on a grand scale before ev cars will match efficiency of a gasoline vehicle
snippet.textOriginal: I love that we are all tuning in to see a bunch of grossly inefficient vehicles for there efficiency 😂🤣😜. snippet.textDisplay:
If you ask me the results should not be who got the furthest. It should be who came closest to their claimed range.
Therefore my ranking when I would get an e-car:
1. Kia - 90%
2. Nissan - 87%
3. Audi - 81%
4. Tesla - 78%
5. Jag - 76%
6. Merc - 75%

Unfortunately the car that actually interest me the most is not in the test:
BMW i3


Still a great "sort of scientific experiment" ;)
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: My limited understanding of batteries are that the more charge and discharge cycles a battery goes through the less power it will hold. snippet.textDisplay: For my day-to-day commuting and household duties an EV would be ideal for me even with 100 mile range, but I think the closing words are a bit bold as 270 miles in a day wouldn't cover longer road trips e.g. London to Glasgow, or heading down through France... I think a full-day's driving range (easy to do 500 miles in a day when hacking across the continent) is about right. Whilst you can top up electric cars on the way relatively quickly, I prefer my stops to be slash-n-dash rather than sitting around the food court of a service station.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel the absolute distance is important, but what percentage you get out of it is even more important. Key factor is environmental temperature the manufacturer quotes with their maximum range indication. At 20C (68F), the battery is in the optimal zone from the battery perspective only. Both cooler and hotter will negatively influence the battery chemistry's ability to output all stored energy. In battery % output at 7C (45F), the variance between the cars in the test is huge. One big difference between these cars may be the battery chemistry, but another the way the manufacturer manages battery temperature both at idle and in use.
snippet.textOriginal: I feel the absolute distance is important, but what percentage you get out of it is even more important. Key factor is environmental temperature the manufacturer quotes with their maximum range indication. At 20C (68F), the battery is in the optimal zone from the battery perspective only. Both cooler and hotter will negatively influence the battery chemistry's ability to output all stored energy. In battery % output at 7C (45F), the variance between the cars in the test is huge. One big difference between these cars may be the battery chemistry, but another the way the manufacturer manages battery temperature both at idle and in use.

snippet.textDisplay: Scrolling through these comments, it is amazing how many people think Kia is more honest and upfront with their range.  None of these automakers have any say what their range is.  They can only “claim” what regulatory bodies allow them to, based on lab controlled testing.  If the tests are not representative of consumer conditions, then blame the WLTP (or EPA in the US).
snippet.textOriginal: Scrolling through these comments, it is amazing how many people think Kia is more honest and upfront with their range.  None of these automakers have any say what their range is.  They can only “claim” what regulatory bodies allow them to, based on lab controlled testing.  If the tests are not representative of consumer conditions, then blame the WLTP (or EPA in the US).

snippet.textDisplay:
Price. An electric car is much simpler than an ICE car (let alone a hybrid). It should have more efficiency from reduced transmission losses. As everything is electric, like heating and regulating electrical power is easy I would assume the build cost to involve a lot less components, routing, cabling, etc.
In a Tesla with 7,000 Li-ion cells that each have a price and need to be connected to get the V and A we need for the kiloWatts power, we could look at consumer prices of those cells and wonder if the price we pay is fair.
I feel we should also look at battery technology: between LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, LiNiMnCoO2, LiFePO4, LiNiCoAlO2, and Li2TiO3 we get much more or less kWh per kg and we get a lot of recharge cycles (up to 7,000) or a very bad number (300). And each of these chemistries can be recharged at very different speeds. (The speed you get from a charge station is one thing - the battery chemistry dictates the upper limit and in exceeding this you cut yourself short on maximum recharge cycles.)
So, an EV needs less maintenance and is cheaper at that. After how many miles/km do you need to replace the battery? How does that impact TCO? What if a Tesla battery could sustain 500 recharge cycles: is the battery chemical waste now, does it have some value still?
snippet.textOriginal:
Price. An electric car is much simpler than an ICE car (let alone a hybrid). It should have more efficiency from reduced transmission losses. As everything is electric, like heating and regulating electrical power is easy I would assume the build cost to involve a lot less components, routing, cabling, etc.
In a Tesla with 7,000 Li-ion cells that each have a price and need to be connected to get the V and A we need for the kiloWatts power, we could look at consumer prices of those cells and wonder if the price we pay is fair.
I feel we should also look at battery technology: between LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, LiNiMnCoO2, LiFePO4, LiNiCoAlO2, and Li2TiO3 we get much more or less kWh per kg and we get a lot of recharge cycles (up to 7,000) or a very bad number (300). And each of these chemistries can be recharged at very different speeds. (The speed you get from a charge station is one thing - the battery chemistry dictates the upper limit and in exceeding this you cut yourself short on maximum recharge cycles.)
So, an EV needs less maintenance and is cheaper at that. After how many miles/km do you need to replace the battery? How does that impact TCO? What if a Tesla battery could sustain 500 recharge cycles: is the battery chemical waste now, does it have some value still?

snippet.textDisplay:
Very nice review on all levels. Realistic range: between 74.9% and 88.5% of manufacturers' range claims. At 7C (~45F) temperature, you'll lose more than 10% easily compared to a warm battery having been charged. These cars were run with climate control (heating - uses a lot of electricity) set to 20C (~68F). You'll see that EV manufacturers offer heated chairs and steering wheels and their users switch of heating, just heating a chair and a steering wheel instead. A good winter coat gives you more range that way. Sat nav? Living in a densely populated and commuted area on the continent, I use it all the time (really always.) It gives me alternatives to roadworks, traffic jams from accidents, queuing and predicts my arrival time. The arrival time being why I really use it.
My Murk ICE does 3.5 liter diesel per 100km (28.6 km/l, 67.2 mpg US or 80.7 mpg UK) on the motorway with summer tires. Now I got new winter tires. The worn ones did slightly worse. The new ones are a bit wider and have a slightly smaller diameter: 5 liters per 100km (20 km/l, 47 mpg US, or 56.5 mpg UK). Extrapolate that to your EV and when you buy new tires, a slightly larger diameter and narrower tire may get you much more range.
snippet.textOriginal:
Very nice review on all levels. Realistic range: between 74.9% and 88.5% of manufacturers' range claims. At 7C (~45F) temperature, you'll lose more than 10% easily compared to a warm battery having been charged. These cars were run with climate control (heating - uses a lot of electricity) set to 20C (~68F). You'll see that EV manufacturers offer heated chairs and steering wheels and their users switch of heating, just heating a chair and a steering wheel instead. A good winter coat gives you more range that way. Sat nav? Living in a densely populated and commuted area on the continent, I use it all the time (really always.) It gives me alternatives to roadworks, traffic jams from accidents, queuing and predicts my arrival time. The arrival time being why I really use it.
My Murk ICE does 3.5 liter diesel per 100km (28.6 km/l, 67.2 mpg US or 80.7 mpg UK) on the motorway with summer tires. Now I got new winter tires. The worn ones did slightly worse. The new ones are a bit wider and have a slightly smaller diameter: 5 liters per 100km (20 km/l, 47 mpg US, or 56.5 mpg UK). Extrapolate that to your EV and when you buy new tires, a slightly larger diameter and narrower tire may get you much more range.

snippet.textDisplay:
My diesel car goes 1,200 km (745 miles) at 80 liters (21 gallons us).

In Norway where I live I can drive from Oslo to my home town Bodø which is 1195 km (742 miles) which according to google says will take 16 hours and 1 minute, so why should i buy electric car and stop several times when i need to stop once. And yes I have driven Bodø-Oslo on an 80 liter tank (21 gallon us) in the winter
